subject: Re: [junit] Using TestResult and accessing its methods
msgSnippet: ... Yes, that was probably due to a transient brain failure of mine... Pleace replace TestRunner with TestResult when reading the previous post. ... OK,
messageBody:
--- David Saff <saff@...> wrote:

> John,
>
> Interesting question. First, I'm confused about whether there's a typo,
>
> and the original message was supposed to say "TestResult" everywhere it
> says "TestRunner".

Yes, that was probably due to a transient brain failure of mine...
Pleace replace TestRunner with TestResult when reading the previous post.

> Second, I think you're best off with modifying the strategy from the
> previous link you give. By design, you don't have access to the current
> TestResult or TestRunner within a TestCase.

OK, thanks, I'll try that :)

--
John

>
> David Saff
>
> John H. E. wrote:
>
> > Hi!
> >
> > I am a beginner JUnit user, and I am not able to find sufficient
> > information in the Documentation on how to use the TestRunner class
> and
> > access its methods.
> >
> > There are a few examples in
> > http://junit.sourceforge.net/doc/cookbook/cookbook.htm, under "Suite",
> but
> > I'm still unsure how to use TestRunner.
> >
> > For example, (how) can I access the TestRunner's methods in the
> tearDown()
> > method of a TestCase subclass? Say that I want to avoid deleting some
> > generated output files if a test has failed (but delete them if the
> test
> > is successful).
> >
> > The methods wasSuccessful(), failureCount() and errorCount() in
> > junit.framework.TestResult look very convenient to use. Is this true?
> >
> > I guess I could use some modified version of what is suggested in the
> > thread http://groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/13151 ("detect test
> > failure in teardown()"), but I want to know more about TestResult
> first...
> >
> > --
> > John
> >
